events.originalText: The state-owned Taedonggang Brewing Company inaugurated the first beer festival in North Korea.
events.subtitle: Taedonggang Brewing Company
events.headline: North Korea's Taedonggang Brewing Company Hosts First Beer Festival

events.originalText: Kursk, an Oscar-class submarine of the Russian Navy, suffered an on-board explosion and sank in the Barents Sea during a military exercise with 118 lives lost.
events.subtitle: Russian submarine Kursk (K-141)
events.headline: Russian Navy's Submarine Kursk Sinks in Barents Sea, 118 Lives Lost

events.originalText: Near Faith, South Dakota, American paleontologist Sue Hendrickson found one of the most complete Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons, nicknamed Sue (pictured).
events.subtitle: Faith, South Dakota
events.headline: American Paleontologist Sue Hendrickson Discovers Complete T. rex Skeleton Near Faith, South Dakota

events.originalText: Japan Air Lines Flight 123 crashed into Mount Takamagahara in Gunma Prefecture, killing 520 of 524 people on board in the world's worst single-aircraft aviation disaster.
events.subtitle: Japan Air Lines Flight 123
events.headline: Japan Air Lines Flight 123 Crashes into Mount Takamagahara, 520 Dead in Aviation Disaster

events.originalText: The Troubles: Riots erupted in the neighbourhood of Bogside in Derry, and spread across much of Northern Ireland.
events.subtitle: The Troubles
events.headline: Riots Break Out in Bogside, Derry, Spreading Across Northern Ireland

events.originalText: Thirteen Jewish poets were executed in Moscow for espionage based on false confessions.
events.subtitle: Night of the Murdered Poets
events.headline: Thirteen Jewish Poets Executed in Moscow for Espionage

events.originalText: An official administrative history of the Manhattan Project, written by American physicist Henry DeWolf Smyth, was released to the public days after the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
events.subtitle: Smyth Report
events.headline: Official History of Manhattan Project Released After Hiroshima and Nagasaki Bombings

events.originalText: World War II: In Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Italy, the Waffen-SS and the Brigate Nere murdered about 560 local villagers and refugees and burned their bodies.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Waffen-SS and Brigate Nere Massacre 560 in Sant'Anna di Stazzema, Italy

events.originalText: World War I: Belgian troops won a victory at the Battle of Halen, but were ultimately unable to stop the German invasion of the country.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Belgian Troops Victorious at Battle of Halen, Unable to Halt German Invasion

events.originalText: The last known quagga (colourised example pictured), a subspecies of the plains zebra, died at Natura Artis Magistra, a zoo in Amsterdam.
events.subtitle: Quagga
events.headline: Last Known Quagga Dies at Natura Artis Magistra Zoo in Amsterdam

events.originalText: Franco-American children as young as seven years old commenced a strike against Cabot Mill of Brunswick, Maine. The Mill had to shut down operations for three days.
events.subtitle: French Americans
events.headline: Franco-American Children Strike Against Cabot Mill, Brunswick, Maine

events.originalText: Crusades: Fatimid forces under al-Afdal Shahanshah began retreating to Egypt after the Battle of Ascalon, concluding the First Crusade.
events.subtitle: Crusades
events.headline: Fatimid Forces Retreat to Egypt After Battle of Ascalon, Ending First Crusade
